speaker: Customer
text: Dr. Crane.  I just wanted to tell you how much I miss your show.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well thank you so much.  I miss it too.  Yes, the brisk interchange of ideas, the crackling interplay between me and my callers.

speaker: Customer
text: [_obviously haven gotten more than he wanted_] Uh-huh.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you're very kind.

speaker: Frasier
text: See that, Roz?  The public still craves the kind of excitement that only Frasier Crane can provide. [_Roz is asleep._] Roz!

speaker: Roz
text: I am so sorry.  The baby kept me up all night long last night. I'm trying to get her used to her crib, but she just hates to sleep alone.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, the acorn certainly doesn't fall far from the...

speaker: Roz
text: I have GOT to wake up.  I'm on my way to an interview. I mean, I'd kill for a cup of regular coffee, but I'm still nursing so I can't.  You know, it was all I could do just to get myself dressed and then feed the baby this morning.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, you know, next time maybe you should try feeding first and dressing second. [_He points to a large stain on her blouse._]

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, my God!  How did I miss this?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... on the plus side, it does divert the eye from the blueberries in your teeth.

speaker: Roz
text: What?!  I can't go to this interview like this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course you can.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I'm just gonna call and cancel.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no, Roz, please!  Just check your teeth, put your jacket on and I swear you'll look every inch the smart career gal on the go.  There.

speaker: Roz
text: Thanks, Frasier.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Roz.  Is that the newest thing, wearin' two different shoes?

speaker: Roz
text: [_looking down_] Oh, my God! [_She hurries out._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Dad.  So, what brings you here?

speaker: Martin
text: [_sitting_] Well, I thought you needed a little cheerin' up.  You've been kinda mopey lately.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I had kind of a rough night at the wine club.  During the blindfolded tasting, I gave four stars to a Mexican Zinfandel.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I don't just mean last night.  You've been kinda down ever since you lost your job, you know?  And you haven't had a date in I don't know how long.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, I know how long, and this isn't the way to cheer me up.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, don't worry, I found a girl for you.  Now, Duke's daughter Marie just moved back in town...

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, blind dates remain the refuge of the lovelorn.

speaker: Martin
text: You know, if you didn't talk like that you might not have to get set up so much.  Now listen, she's not a blind date, you know Marie, you spent a week with her at the lake.

speaker: Frasier
text: She was six years old!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, Duke said she's grown into a real looker.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well I have SEEN Duke, and unless he sired a love child with Catherine Deneuve, I don't like my odds.

speaker: Marie
text: Uncle Martin.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, Marie!  Look at you!  You remember Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: _Bonjour_. **BON SOIR** _Scene 2 - Frasier's Apartment Fade in.  Frasier and Marie are at the table, finishing dinner._

speaker: Marie
text: I don't know when I've had such a delicious meal.  You really made this dessert yourself?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes.  A little something I like to call "Crane Br�lee."

speaker: Frasier
text: Is everything all right there?

speaker: Marie
text: Oh, it's just a little quirk of mine.  I like to keep things straight.  You know, in parallel lines.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I noticed that earlier with the asparagus.

speaker: Marie
text: It's weird, I know.  It used to drive my mother crazy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, we all have our little idiosyncrasies.  How is your mother, anyway?

speaker: Marie
text: Still in my face.  After the divorce, things just got worse. [_She adjusts his silverware._] Oh, I'm doing it again, aren't I?  I'm sorry, I'll stop.  Look. [_She deliberately places a spoon at an odd angle._] Anyway, I haven't figured out how to have a normal relationship with her.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, we're all striving to have what we call "normal relationships," but who really knows what normal is?  You can move it back now.

speaker: Marie
text: [_putting the spoon back in its place_] Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_rising_] What do you say we have our wine out on the balcony?

speaker: Marie
text: The balcony?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, you haven't had a chance to see the view.  _Frasier opens the balcony door by the table for her, Marie rises, then stumbles against the bookshelf and halts at the step below the door._

speaker: Marie
text: Oh, wow!  That is some view all right!  Beautiful.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're afraid of heights, aren't you?

speaker: Marie
text: I'm taking classes.  They give us these exercises to do, they just work better when you're standing on a little milk crate.  Oh, I must seem totally neurotic.  _She sits on the couch and begins arranging the books on the coffee table._

speaker: Frasier
text: Not at all.

speaker: Marie
text: I guess I'm going a little nuts since I moved back in with my dad.  Thank God I'm getting my own place next week.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I suspect that will help a lot.  You know, very often, the key to mental health is distancing ourselves from our parents.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm home!  Oh, hey, sorry to barge in on you kids.

speaker: Marie
text: That's all right, why don't you join us for dessert.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, thanks anyway, but I had "Crane Br�lee" for lunch.

speaker: Frasier
text: I had to do a little dry run earlier, wanted to make sure my caramelizer wasn't on the fritz.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I was pretty proud the first time he brought that blow-torch home.  'Til I saw what it was for.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad!

speaker: Martin
text: No, no, I'm only jokin'.  She knows that.  He's a great kid, Marie.  Sure, he's out of work now, but he's hit the skids a lot of times, but he always manages to bounce right back up.

speaker: Frasier
text: I think you've spread enough pixie dust for one evening, Dad. Thank you.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, yeah, well, goodnight you two. [_He goes to his bedroom._]

speaker: Marie
text: [_rising_] I should probably get going too.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.

speaker: Marie
text: Thank you for a great evening.  And for all the wonderful advice, it was very insightful.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're quite welcome, Marie.  Perhaps you can offer me a little insight as well: will this be our only night together, or will I see you again?

speaker: Marie
text: Well, you're pretty good at interpreting things, maybe this will answer your question.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.  Well, then you have a nice life.  _Marie smiles, Frasier looks a little stunned.  Fade out.  Scene 3 - Cafe Nervosa Fade in.  Frasier and Marie are talking over coffee._

speaker: Marie
text: ...and just as this hunter catches up to me, and is about to kill me, I wake up on the cot in my dad's oak-paneled rumpus room.

speaker: Frasier
text: That is a terrifying nightmare.  Are there any other figures in the rumpus room?

speaker: Marie
text: No, that's not part of the dream.  I really sleep there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, oh.

speaker: Marie
text: [_getting up_] I wish I didn't have to go.  Can we talk more about this after the museum tonight?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, of course.  I thought it was the opera tonight.

speaker: Marie
text: No, the museum opening.  You promised me in the shower this morning, remember?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well I was under duress.  You had a loofah to my head. _She leaves past Niles, who walks up to Frasier with a shocked look on his face._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles, you just missed Duke's daughter.

speaker: Niles
text: [_sitting_] I saw.  Is it possible that's the same little girl that we used to refer to as "The Ugly Dukeling"?  She is stunning.

speaker: Frasier
text: Isn't she, though?  You know, the insecure part of me is having trouble figuring out why she's going out with me. She could have her pick of men.  And I am a little older, haven't been to the gym as often as I should, and you can feel free to contradict me anytime you like, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: You must have something, because she's clearly charmed by you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, whatever the reason, we certainly have the most wonderful time together.  We have the greatest discussions. Oh, I've been helping her sort through some of her issues.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, really?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, it's a very complex relationship with her mother, giving rise to several striking phobias, recurring dreams, the most charming little obsessive-compulsive disorder.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, well, there you go!  Perhaps she's attracted to you because of your psychiatric expertise.

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you suggesting, Niles?  That Marie is going out with me just to get free therapy?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, it was just a thought.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's a mean-spirited thought!  Marie is not using me.  She would want me just as much even if I weren't a psychiatrist. You know, you're jealous!  You're jealous that I'm having sex! Jealous that I'm having hot, passionate, sweaty jungle sex! What are you having?!

speaker: Niles
text: [_to the stunned waitress_] I'm having a latte.  _Scene 4 - Frasier's Apartment Fade in.  Martin is out on the balcony, talking on the phone._

speaker: Martin
text: Will this be all right for ya?  Yeah, I'm telling you, Phil, she's really cute.  You'll see for yourself in a coupla minutes. [_Daphne comes in the front._] Oh, wait, she's comin' in now, I gotta go.

speaker: Martin
text: [_coming in_] Hey, Daphne, how's it goin'?

speaker: Daphne
text: Fine.

speaker: Martin
text: Good.

speaker: Daphne
text: What are you so chipper about?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, nothin'.  It's a beautiful night out.  Say, why don't you come out and have a look at the moon with me?

speaker: Daphne
text: Why?  Is it full?

speaker: Martin
text: [_grinning_] I don't know.

speaker: Daphne
text: All right.

speaker: Martin
text: Beaut, isn't it?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, yeah, very romantic. [_She turns to go back in._]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, now, wait come here.  I gotta show you somethin' else. Over here.  Ah, look at that, the way those moonbeams bounce off that reflecting pool.  _Daphne looks down at the scene while Martin makes "Well?" looks up across the way._

speaker: Daphne
text: Ah, yeah, that's really something. [_noticing him_] What are you doing?

speaker: Martin
text: Nothing.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, you are.

speaker: Martin
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, you are.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm not.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes you are, you're signaling to someone.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, all right.  I did such a good job with Frasier, I thought maybe I could fix you up with some nice guy.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_searching_] Is it that man up there with the binoculars?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, isn't that a great building?  He does real well, he owns half that floor.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_smacking him in the chest_] Oh, Mr. Crane!

speaker: Martin
text: What?  _Daphne goes inside, Martin following.  Cut to the inside of the apartment._

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't believe it!  Putting me on display like a bloody concubine! [_She stomps off to her room._]

speaker: Martin
text: [_calling after her_] Well, you get a turn too.  I got this telescope set up so you can have a look at him. [_The phone rings._] See, he likes you! [_answers_] Hello?  Yeah, well I told you she was pretty!  What do you mean, can I show you another one?  What do you think I'm running here?

speaker: Marie
text: So there I am, actually biting the fingernails of the same hand that's holding the phone not two minutes after I'm on with my mother.  Isn't that so revealing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes, I'd say it is.

speaker: Marie
text: [_sitting on the couch_] Is everything OK, Frasier?  You seem a little quiet.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, I was just so enjoying our museum chat and I was wondering how we got onto the subject of mothers.

speaker: Marie
text: Well, it was a Whistler exhibit.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, I'm sorry.  I guess I'm just a bit tense.

speaker: Marie
text: Well, why didn't you say something?  I can give you a little massage.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, really, well all right.  If you think that will help.  _He sits on the couch, Marie kneels behind him and starts rubbing his neck and shoulders._

speaker: Marie
text: It's such an amazing feeling, being in the presence of so much beauty.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well you say that now, in six weeks you'll be telling me to lose weight. [_They share a laugh._] The Whistler, I know, I know.  Gosh isn't it great that we both enjoy art so much?  I could just talk about it all night.

speaker: Marie
text: Me too.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you know, I couldn't help notice you staring at that riverscape.  You couldn't take your eyes off it.

speaker: Marie
text: I think it's because it reminded me of my recurring dream. You know, we were going to talk more about that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes, yes.  The dream, being pursued by the hunter and the arrows...

speaker: Marie
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, uh, you know, I don't really feel like I'm up to talking about that now.  Do you think we can do it some other night?

speaker: Marie
text: All right.  What did you think of the riverscape?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well, I, uh, I enjoyed it.  I was also enjoying what you were doing just now.

speaker: Marie
text: Oh, I'm sorry.  My hands were just getting a little bit of a cramp.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well then let me do you, then.

speaker: Marie
text: Actually, it's getting late.  You know, maybe I should get home.

speaker: Frasier
text: I thought you were gonna spend the night.

speaker: Marie
text: I'd like to, but I have an early morning and I hate to rush.  Had a great evening tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, about that dream, uh, I did have one thought.

speaker: Marie
text: Really?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Forest imagery...very often represents our most primal emotions.  Hence its frequent use in fairy tales. Which could be a link to your childhood.

speaker: Marie
text: You are so good at this.  Much better than my therapist.

speaker: Frasier
text: You have a therapist?

speaker: Marie
text: Not anymore.  Who can afford it?  Anyway...  You know, my hands are feeling much better, why don't we give that massage another shot?  So I notice that I often have this dream right after I talk to my mother.  Oh, your muscles are so tense!  Is it just your neck, or is it all over?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_thinking of the relationship_] It's all over.  _Fade out.  End of Act 1  Act 2  Scene 1 - Cafe Nervosa Fade in.  Roz is at a table and calls Frasier over._

speaker: Roz
text: [_very fast_] Frasier!  Frasier!  You will not believe this! Little Alice said her first word today.  It was "Ma."  Or it may have been "moo."  Mary, that's the sitter, gave her this little toy cow.  She's always doing stuff like that.  I love Mary.  I love this little cow, too.  It's the cutest little thing, it's brown and white, well that's a jersey cow, right? Well that's where Mary's from, Jersey. [_to a passing waiter_] Yeah I'll take a splash more! [_he pours_] You know, I stopped nursing yesterday and boy have I missed this stuff.  Cup of mud, java, my old friend Joe - Oh, that's funny, Mary's husband's name is Joe.  Oh, my God, he's picking her up, I gotta go, this has been fun, you look great, nice talking with you.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, may I join you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, of course, Niles.  And I'm sorry about yesterday.

speaker: Niles
text: No, no I'm the one who should be apologizing.  I never meant to suggest Marie was...

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, Marie and I broke up.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry.  Did she at least give you a reason?

speaker: Frasier
text: I broke up with her.  But thank you for the daily shot in the arm of confidence.

speaker: Martin
text: I just talked to Duke.  What the hell did you break up with Marie for?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, listen, I'm terribly sorry.  I don't mean to cause a rift between you and your friend, but I couldn't continue with it. You see, once I confirmed that Marie was primarily interested in me as a sounding board for her problems, I just had to end it.  Just as Niles suggested I should.  _Martin, upon hearing this, smacks Niles on the shoulder, who hits Frasier, who hits him back._

speaker: Niles
text: I never suggested that!  No, all I said was that one of the things she might appreciate about you was your psychiatric expertise.  For heaven's sake, if you were a world-class chef, she'd appreciate your cooking, if you were a stand-up comic, she'd appreciate your jokes.

speaker: Martin
text: If you were a dermatologist, and she had a big growth comin' out of her face...

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Dad, I get it.

speaker: Niles
text: I am sorry, but if you had let the relationship continue, she might have found other things that she'd appreciate about you just as much.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_getting up_] You know, maybe there's still time to win her back.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, it'd take a pretty big bouquet of flowers to do that.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know, Dad.  Maybe if I just explain to her what really happened, she'll forgive me.  Sometimes the best apology is just the truth.

speaker: Niles
text: You mean you're going to tell her you thought she was prostituting herself for therapy but now you've decided that's OK?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_pause_] Well, not that truth.  Some other truth.   **IS THAT PORK IN YOUR CUFF OR ARE YOU JUST GLAD TO SEE ME?**  _Scene 2 - Frasier's Apartment Fade in.  Martin is sitting in his chair, Marie and Frasier come in._

speaker: Frasier
text: Evening Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, you two.  How was dinner?

speaker: Marie
text: It was just great.  We went to my favorite restaurant. It's this little Korean barbecue.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  It's just fabulous.  You get to cook your own food on this little grill that's right in the center of the table. It splatters a little bit, but you know, that's what makes it fun.

speaker: Niles
text: [_picking something off Frasier's shirt_] Clearly you had a marvelous time.  Oh, hello again, Marie.

speaker: Marie
text: Hi, Niles.  If we're gonna go away this weekend, I should make reservations.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.  I tell you what, just use the phone in my bedroom and I'll be in in a minute.

speaker: Marie
text: Actually, just thinking about getting away is making me more relaxed already.  _She heads towards Frasier's room, using her hands to shield her eyes from the view of the balcony._

speaker: Frasier
text: She has a little problem with heights.

speaker: Niles
text: I saw that.

speaker: Martin
text: [_rising_] Well, I'm sure glad you two patched things up, anyway.  You know, Duke and I go back a long way.  I got a lot of friends but there's somethin' I get from Duke that I don't get from anybody else.

speaker: Frasier
text: Seahawks tickets.

speaker: Martin
text: And don't think that SOB wasn't ready to pull 'em, either. _Martin goes off to his room.  Frasier and Niles head to the kitchen. Cut to the kitchen as Niles gets a bag of popcorn out of the microwave and Frasier pours two glasses of wine._

speaker: Niles
text: Dad dragged me to one of those Korean barbecues once.  Had that suit dry-cleaned three times, Eddie still greets me in a carnivorous frenzy every time I wear it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well the next time Marie and I go out to dinner, I'm going to pick the restaurant.  Preferably, one where the stove gets its own room.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, she certainly seems smitten with you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, she certainly does, doesn't she?  And I am quite captivated with her.  You know, I can't put my finger on exactly why.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm just glad things are going well for you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are they ever.  I find her more enchanting each day.  You know what?  And I am particularly intrigued by this recurring dream she has.  She's in the woods, she's being pursued by a hunter and get this, when she turns to confront her pursuer, the hunter has no face.

speaker: Niles
text: Fascinating.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm determined to get to the bottom of it.  I'm certain it could shed light on her mother issues, and this fear of heights and, oh God, I just discovered that she absolutely refuses to touch a doorknob with her bare hand.  Thanks to my natural chivalry, I missed that for a whole week.

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, is that all you talk about, her problems?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, no, no, we talk about lots of things.  Art, the theater, why?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, it's just a passing thought.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, pass it over here.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you were asking what most captivated you about her. Perhaps she's giving you a chance to exercise your psychiatric muscles.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you have been out of work for a while...

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, Marie is a stunning woman with a body to die for, and you think all I'm interested in is her mind?  How shallow do you think I am?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, there's no need to get defensive.  There's not a problem.  Unless, she's falling in love with you and you're only interested in her as a case study.

speaker: Frasier
text: I assure you I'm interested in all aspects of Marie, not just her psyche.  For God's sake, you know I could happily go for weeks without discussing it once.

speaker: Niles
text: Glad to hear it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thank you.  If you'll excuse me, I have someone waiting for me in the other room.  _He leaves the kitchen.  Cut to the living room as Eddie rushes up and chomps down on his pants cuff.  Frasier crosses the living room dragging him along._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, oh, dear God!  Unhand me you wretch!  Oh, you vile creature!  Oh, for God's sake, you miserable mutt!  Niles, please!  Throw him a Liv-A-Snap!  Get off of me!  _Cut to Frasier's room.  Marie is on the bed, Frasier comes in, still fighting off Eddie._

speaker: Frasier
text: Just let go of that leg, you, this instant!

speaker: Frasier
text: My father's best friend.  Well, after your father.

speaker: Marie
text: We're all booked for this weekend.  There's a lake, hiking, sounds like the perfect place to relax. [_He hands her a glass of wine and climbs on the bed with her._]

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I do love the country, so relaxing.  I swear to God, I am out like a light as soon as my head hits the pillow.

speaker: Marie
text: Then we'll have to ask for a room with no pillows.  Oh! That reminds me, I had that dream again.  But this time I saw the hunter's face.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Marie
text: Yeah.  You'll never guess who it was.

speaker: Frasier
text: Who?  No, no.

speaker: Marie
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, I'd just really rather not discuss the dream right now.

speaker: Marie
text: Oh, you're right.  I'm sorry.  Like you even care about who the hunter is right now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, when there's so many other things I'm interested in. There, that's better isn't it?

speaker: Marie
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: You feel relaxed?

speaker: Marie
text: Uh-huh.

speaker: Frasier
text: Was it your sister?

speaker: Marie
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: The hunter.  It was your sister, wasn't it?

speaker: Marie
text: No.  I thought you didn't want to talk about this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, God, you're right.  I don't.  I really, really don't. I'd much rather be exploring other things right now, like your lips.  And your chin.  And your neck.

speaker: Marie
text: Ohh, keep going.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, for God's sake, who was it?!

speaker: Marie
text: What is with you?

speaker: Frasier
text: I just have to know.

speaker: Marie
text: OK.  It was me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course it was!  The hunter represents your feelings of anger and abandonment that you've been running from ever since your parents' divorce!  Until now, you've been able to avoid those painful areas, sometimes hiding in the forest of repression!  Now, your willingness to identify the hunter signals that you are now ready to, to reintegrate these complex emotions into a more cohesive self!

speaker: Marie
text: Wow!  It's all so clear now!

speaker: Frasier
text: It certainly is!

speaker: Marie
text: That was amazing.  I am so glad I gave you a second chance.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Marie, I...

speaker: Marie
text: Please, don't apologize.  Maybe someday it'll be some funny story we tell our grandkids.  The time grandpa broke up with grandma.

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, grandma...

speaker: Marie
text: Yes?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm afraid this isn't gonna work.

speaker: Marie
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Us.  I'm afraid that...

speaker: Marie
text: Wait a minute.  Am I crazy, or are you breaking up with me again?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, they're not completely unrelated.  You see, you are a beautiful young woman and I have really enjoyed tackling some of these issues with you, it's just that I don't think that's the basis for a relationship.  I think you deserve someone who appreciates all you have to offer.

speaker: Marie
text: I don't believe this.

speaker: Frasier
text: I just feel more like your therapist than your boyfriend.

speaker: Marie
text: But I thought we were having such a good time together.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm afraid our time is up.

speaker: Martin
text: This weekend's game?  Well, yeah, I want 'em, Duke... Seahawks - Chiefs?  Are you kidding?  I'll pick 'em up tomorrow.  Hey, wouldn't it be a kick if we wound up in- laws?

speaker: Marie
text: [_off stage_] Go to hell!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, hold on a sec.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_off stage_] Good, embrace the anger, it's the best way to mental health.

speaker: Marie
text: I don't need health tips from you, you quack.  _She storms in from the hall, again blocking the balcony with her hands.  Frasier follows._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I think you've made real progress in the time we've been together.

speaker: Marie
text: Oh, don't flatter yourself.

speaker: Frasier
text: I have the name of a specialist.

speaker: Marie
text: Call him yourself! [_She slams the door on her way out._]

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Duke, I'm gonna be kinda busy tomorrow, uh, maybe you could just drop those tickets in the mail right now so you don't forget.
